subject: Marketing
title: The Anchoring Effect
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Anchoring Effect.

hook.text: A store prices a jacket at $500, then marks it down to $200. It feels like a steal.

buildup.text: The first number you see becomes your mental anchor for everything after.

discovery.text: Anchoring bias means we rely too heavily on the first piece of information we get.

twist.text: Even random numbers influence judgment. Anchors work whether they're relevant or not.

climax.text: Premium brands set high anchors so their standard price looks reasonable.

punchline.text: The first number wins the negotiation.

quiz.question: What is the anchoring effect in pricing?
options: The first price seen sets the reference for all later judgments
Customers always choose the cheapest option available
Repeated discounts make products seem less valuable
